Award.AwardTitle: RESEARCH INITIATION AWARD GRANT: STATISTICAL MODELS FOR REAL-TIME PARAMETER PREDICTION FROM PROBE VEHICLE DATA AT TRAFFIC INTERSECTIONS

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of the project entitled: Statistical Models for Real-Time Parameter Prediction from Probe Vehicle Data at Traffic Intersections, are to develop new queue length estimate models at traffic intersections, to teach undergraduate students mathematical and computational modeling skills, and to develop project based undergraduate courses.

The project will investigate the estimation of system parameters such as queue length, delay, and flow rate at traffic intersections based on data from vehicles instrumented with wireless communication and location tracking technologies, so called probe vehicles. Estimating system states in real-time can enable optimal control through efficiently allocating the available capacity such that a defined performance metric is optimized, for example the queue length is minimized. To estimate these performance measures in real time, various surveillance technologies are being employed to measure traffic flow parameters which are subsequently utilized in models for delay estimation and prediction. However, these detection technologies are not effective in estimating queue lengths or delays. Research is needed to develop models using probe information such as count, location, and time, and to understand how probe vehicle technology could potentially improve the estimation of desired parameters. During this project,first queue length estimators for two-lane isolated intersections with left and right turn movements for Poisson arrivals, then platoon arrivals will be developed. Fixed and random service time distributions will be investigated. Finally, developed models will be tested with VISSIM microscopic simulation platform in order to show if the models are accurately estimating the desired parameters and under what conditions the models are adequate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed queue length estimation (QLE) models for the data from GPS/cell phone tracked vehicles at isolated intersections. Several parts of this problem are tackled during the project. First, the cases when arrival rate and connected vehicle penetration rates are considered as unknown which will typically be the case in real life applications. Alternative estimators for these parameters are formulated and their behaviors under various scenarios are given. Second, different arrival distributions are incorporated into the models. So far, QLE models are derived under Poisson (Random-Moderate to low traffic) arrivals. However, bunching effect of the vehicles at moderate to high traffic is also needed to be addressed. Some distribution from literature both traffic/other disciplines are used in this part. An analytical approximations for different arrival distributions are developed. Third, a microscopic simulation is used to mimic the real life data and models are evaluated. In this section, possible implementation of these models in an adaptive signal heuristic is also tackled. Some codes in Excel Visual Basic and C++ are written. Simple C++ point queue simulations are initially used if QLE models are able to give reliable results for signal control and if they indeed increase the performances over typical actuated traffic signals. In the last step, possible inclusion of vehicle types, GPS errors, and multiple lane intersection are also discussed. Currently 1 journal article and 6 conference abstracts are published. Two more journal articles are in preparation to be sent. Briefly activities can be listed as:

  1. Total of 12 directly (paid), 5 indirectly (voluntary-benefited without pay) students, and 2 faculty had research experience from this program. Students were exposed to R-project, MatLab, C#, and Excel Visual Basic coding environments.
  2. Students’ majors included Transportation Engineering and Logistics Studies, Electrical Engineering, Biology, Physics, Computer Engineering, and Computer Science.
  3. Directly or indirectly after this research, two students graduated and started to work as engineers in well-known manufacturing companies. Two students did another internship in Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, California. One student participated at exchange student program in Colombia. Indirectly participated students (i.e., attended meetings and wrote research abstract with PI), one student did internship at Princeton University in summer 2014, and one student started PhD program in Mechanical Engineering at University of South Carolina in Fall 2014, one student is studying a MS degree in Electrical Engineering at Norfolk State University.
  4. One student presented poster in 2013 TRB, Washington D.C. meeting.
  5. One student received D.D. Eisenhower Transportation Fellowship for 2013-2014 and 2014-2015 academic years.
  6. Students presented 1 poster in the student research day at the College and 1 oral presentation at 2013 South Carolina Academy of Sciences annual Meeting.
  7. Students did 3 oral presentations at 2014 Transportation Summit on March 22, 2014 and learned about career opportunities through meeting with the professionals from transportation field.
  8.
